isis.stitle: 7 SPEED TRANSMISSIONS FULLER SERIES - REASSEMBLE - MAIN DRIVE GEAR

step1.para: If previously removed, install the snap ring in the I.D. of the main drive gear ( Figure 103) and bushing in the pocket of the input shaft (inset).

figure.caption: Figure 103. Install Snap Ring in I.D. of Main Drive Gear

step1.para: Install drive gear on the input shaft, engaging the internal splines of the gear with the teeth on the shaft, snap ring of the gear to the front of the shaft ( Figure 104).

figure.caption: Figure 104. Install Drive Gear on Input Shaft

step1.para: Install the drive gear spacer on the input shaft and against the gear ( Figure 105).

figure.caption: Figure 105. Install Drive Gear Spacer on Input Shaft

step1.para: Press the drive gear bearing on the input shaft, bearing shield to the front of the shaft ( Figure 106), or use a flanged bearing driver (inset).

figure.caption: Figure 106. Press Drive Gear Bearing on Input shaft

step1.para: Apply Loctite grade 277 sealant to the cleaned threads of the new drive gear bearing nut ( Figure 107). DO NOT RE-USE THE OLD NUT.

figure.caption: Figure 107. Apply Sealant to Threads of New Drive Gear Bearing Nut

note.para: Models otherwise equipped with a snap ring to retain the bearing, install the snap ring in the groove of the input shaft and proceed to Step 8.

step1.para: Mount assembly in a vise, pilot end up, and secure on the drive gear O.D. Vise used should be equipped with brass jaws or wood blocks to prevent damage to gear teeth. Clean threads of input shaft and install drive gear bearing nut on the shaft (left, Figure 108). Use a drive gear bearing nut installer to tighten the nut on the input shaft, left-hand threads, to 250 to 300 ft-lbs. (339 to 407 N· m) (right).

figure.caption: Figure 108. Install Drive Gear Bearing Nut and Tighten

step1.para: Use a punch and maul to peen nut into the two milled slots of the input shaft ( Figure 109).

figure.caption: Figure 109. Peen Nut into Slots of Input Shaft

step1.para: Remove assembly from the vise to mark the main drive gear for timing purposes ( Figure 110). Mark any two adjacent teeth on the drive gear and repeat the procedure for the two adjacent teeth directly opposite the first set marked. A highly visible color of toolmaker's dye is recommended for making timing marks.

figure.caption: Figure 110. Mark Main Drive Gear For Timing Purposes
